title: Setup Maglev Development Cluster
content:
Maglev provides a development cluster provisioned in our lab environment. This cluster consists of all Maglev components and services.

Creating a cluster using Tesseract DevCloud

Bug Bhavik (bhavipa2) to add you as a user on DevCloud
Once you have access, login to http://dev-tesseract.cisco.com/
Follow the onscreen wizard to create a cluster. At the time of creation, choose the right appstack (maglev or ndp etc.,). Choose the required build (latest is better)
You will receive an email when your cluster has been created, with access details.

 Note: Unification Branch, ISO is not yet released

title: Getting Started
content:
Getting started with DNAC plugin development

Follow these steps to create and run your first plugin:
 Cluster based Development

Deploy a cluster via http://dev-tesseract.cisco.com/

Install Tooling (DPM)
     npm -g install @cisco-dna/dpm --registry http://engci-maven-master.cisco.com/artifactory/api/npm/apic-em-npm-group/

Create and start a dev server for your plugin:
     dpm create myPlugin && cd myPlugin && dpm start -s

Visit https://localhost:3002 and accept the security warning.

    
Point your cluster to your local dev server:
    Visit https://cluster-ip/developer
    Add https://localhost:3002/ui-config.json as a dev config url

    
Visit https://cluster-ip/myPlugin.  You should see stuff.

Platform based Development

Install Tooling (DPM)

     npm -g install @cisco-dna/dpm --registry http://engci-maven-master.cisco.com/artifactory/api/npm/apic-em-npm-group/

Create and start a dev server for your plugin:

     dpm create myPlugin && cd myPlugin && dpm start

Clone the platformui repository at https://sjc-apl-grt28.cisco.com:8081//admin/projects/platformui.

Start a local platform instance:

     cd ui && dev-env-setup && dev-start

Visit http://localhost:3001/developer

Add http://localhost:3002/ui-config.json as a dev config url

http://localhost:3001/myPlugin. You should see a welcome message!

Plugin Manifest (ui-config.js)

This file, generated as part of your plugin's boilerplate, describes your plugin and how it extends the platform.  It looks something like this:
module.exports = ( ) =   : { 
  return  ,
      modulePreload,
      contributions:  
        ]
       
     
   
 
 Contributions
Generally, platform extensions are defined via contributions.  Plugins can also make themselves extensible in arbitrary ways via extensionPoints.  More detail on this can be found here.

Often, extensionPoints require contributions to point to some Javascript module that implements a particular interface, the details of which depend on the extensionPoint. The assetRef function is a way to reference such modules.  At build time, DPM outputs a ui-config.json with assetRefs replaced with final hashed module names.  More on that here.

Notice that a route contribution is specified.  When the /myPlugin path is visited in the browser, the view defined in the plugin's Plugin.js module will render.  Here's what Plugin.js looks like:

import styles from "./Plugin.scss"

const createView = () =  )  ,
    dispose() { 
   
 

export default createView

Try changing this code while your dev server is running.  When you save, the browser will refresh automatically.  You can also change css (the Plugin.scss file) and the page will auto update.

Rendering UI

 Platform Shell

The platform shell provides extension points for assigning views to specific url routes.

Using a view framework

The platform doesn't care how your plugin renders views, so long as it can return a DOM node when asked.  More discussion on this here.

Most view frameworks can be used.  For React users, a utility library is provided to easily adapt React components to platform generic views.

 Bootstrap CSS

Bootstrap CSS class names can be used in DOM markup.  The DNAC platform's pre-loads a customized Bootstrap theme that conforms to DNAC cohesion styling.  The DNA Bootstrap guide can be found here.

Platform Web Components

The DNA UI platform is pre-packaged with a number of Web Components that can be leveraged to take advantage of common functionality and look and feel.  These are exposed as custom html tags, so they can generally be used via any view rendering framework.

 Custom URL routing

Shell Service
The shell provides APIs for obtaining/manipulating the current route and query parameters, and checking whether or not a route matches a given pattern.  These APIs can be used to conditionally render views, and change the current route based on user actions.

 Routing libraries
Generally, routing libraries such as react-router can be used by plugins to manage their own routes, the caveat being that they'll generally be unaware of route changes that happen outside of their control, without you adding some extra logic.

At build time, DPM outputs a ui-config.json with assetRefs replaced with final hashed module names.  More on that here.

 Views

Using a view framework

title: AssetRef Plugin
content:
AssetRef Plugin

Webpack Plugin to convert ui-confg.js to ui-config.json with module path entry.

 Install

In your UI plugin project:
 
 
 set registry="http://engci-maven-master.cisco.com/artifactory/api/npm/apic-em-npm-group/"
 
	npm install @cisco-dna/asset-ref-plugin

Why Is This Useful?

When working with DNA UI Plugin,ui-config.json is the configuration file is what the UI platform sees at runtime.

It is important to add the capability for referencing your plugin's javascript modules or assets such as image, svg, font, etc., files which had been created during the build time.  

This plug-in outputs the ui-config.json file with the paths of the generated assets. 

Example output:

The output is a JSON object in the form:

	 

For example, given the following ui-config.js and webpack config:

ui-config.js

module.exports = ( ) =  ,
            "contributions":  ]
             
         
    	 
 

webpack config

const AssetRefPlugin = require("@cisco-dna/asset-ref-plugin");
module.exports =  ,
	    output:  ,
	    plugins: [new AssetRefPlugin( )]
	 ;

The plugin will output the following json file:

	 ,
	    "contributions":  
	      ]
	     
	   
	 

 Options

You can pass the following options:
	
configFilePath: ui-config.js file Location. ex: /path/to/ui-config.js
	
srcPath - Source path of the asset file.

outputPath -  Output path for ui-config.json.(relative to the output path of webpack)

watch mode

 ui-config.js and the assets  also will be watch for any changes in watch mode.
 
 	webpack --config=webpack.config --watch
 	
 webpack compile Output

title: Plugin Contribution Model
content:
Plugin Contribution Model

 Overview

The contribution model is the mechanism in the DNA UI framework that allows plugins to contribute functionality to the overall system.  As the system itself is composed of plugins, this means that any DNA plugin can both receive and provide contributions from or to other plugins.

A plugin that receives contributions does so without having any advance knowledge about which particular plugins will be contributing.  It has no source or build time dependencies on such plugins, and makes no assumptions about where such plugins physically live.  For instance their source artifacts might be remote, or might be co-located on the same file system.

At it's very core, a contribution is really just a piece of data shared between plugins.  This data is specified declaratively via a plugin's ui-config.json.  Let's take a look at what this means.

Configuration

 Hosting Plugin

A plugin that wants to receive contributions should declare this fact in its ui-config.json, via the extensionPoints attribute.  In this document, we refer to plugins that receive contributions as hosting plugins.

Lets start out with a basic example:

ui-config.json

 ,
      "resultWidget": { 
     
   
 

Each key in the extensionPoints object represents a kind of contribution.  Key names (e.g. resultsProvider) can be arbitrarily chosen by the hosting plugin, and should indicate the type of contribution expected.  The values are objects, and should specify metadata, in the form of a JSON schema, indicating the expected shape of a contribution, as well as documentation for each expected attribute.  Contributions are validated against these schemas at runtime, and are rejected if they don't pass.

Following is an example with the schemas filled out:

ui-config.json

 
           ,
          "module":  
         ,
        "required": ["module"]
       ,
      ...
     
   
 

The above says that each resultsProvider must specify a module property, and can optionally provide a role property.  Each property has a type - roles should be an array of strings, and module is of a pre-defined type called module (more on modules later).

Now, lets take a look at the contributing plugin.

Contributing Plugin

As you might have guessed, the example above represents a hypothetical search plugin that can receive search result contributions.

A plugin that wants to contribute specifies this fact in its ui-config.json, like so:

ui-config.json

 ]
     
   
 

Above, we specify that we're contributing a resultsProvider to the cisco.dna.core.search plugin.  The module property refers to an AMD JavaScript module that will get loaded (via require), whenever the hosting plugin needs to use it.

The module specified above would generally be expected by the hosting plugin to implement a specific interface.

 Contribution API

Hosting plugins can use the contribution API to query the system about which plugins contribute to one of its extension points.  To ask for the resultsProvider contributions, our cisco.dna.core.search plugin could do the following:

dna/core/search/Search.js

require(["external/core/utils/PluginContributions"], function(PluginContributions)  )

The forExtensionPoint API returns an array of contribution objects.  Each has the following properties:

sourcePluginId - a string indicating the contributing plugin's id.
data - the data contributed by the plugin.  In our example, our contributing plugin provides a module (and optionally could have provided role, per the extension point schema).
loadModule() - this is a function that loads the module specified by the contribution.  An extension point might expect a different property value for modules, or might even have multiple properties specifying modules.  For example, if it expected the attribute view to specify a module, it would invoke loadModule(contrib.data.view).  If no argument is passed, you get the equivalent of calling loadModule(contrib.data.module).  This function returns a Promise which resolves to whatever the module exports.

Here's an example of how we might implement search, by aggregating results from resultProvider implementations:

dna/core/search/Search.js

require(["external/core/utils/PluginContributions"], function(PluginContributions)  
  return performSearch
 )

With the above, we now have a search implementation that delegates search queries to contributing plugins and gathers the results.  This is a simplistic implementation of course - a more serious one would have to deal with pagination and probably more.

Hopefully, from looking at the above, you were able to imagine what a contributing plugin's implementation of a resultProvider would look look like.  If not, here's a hypothetical one to nudge your imagination along:

dna/core/userManagement/UserSearchResultsProvider.js

require([/.../], function(/.../)  )
        .map(user = (  ))
     
   
 )

Above, we've imagined that we lookup users with a matching name in the database, and return a result object for each one (with contrived attributes).

Contributing UI

What if we want to receive UI contributions?  In other words, what if we want allow other plugins to participate in the rendering of our views?

Turns out that we already have the mechanics in place.

To render something on a web page, we ultimately need to insert a node somewhere within the DOM.  These days there are zillions of different view libraries and frameworks that help one do this:

const element = document.createElement("div")
// ...populate the element's attributes and children,
// perhaps using your favorite view framework.
document.body.appendChild(element)

 Generic View Interface
If we want to receive view contributions from a plugin, we can require it to export a function that can create a DOM element with its view content when we need it.  We can do this without imposing use of particular view framework by the contributing plugins.  From the perspective of the UI platform and plugins, the view framework is the DOM.

With this in mind, plugins contributing views should implement an interface that matches the following:

export default function createView()  ,
    /**
     Optional method - should perform any necessary cleanup.
     */
    dispose()  
   
 

A hosting plugin invokes this at the time it is needed, passing context that the contributor might use to figure out exactly what to render.  Think of context as the data you might use to render a handlebars template, or props you would use to render a React component.

If the context gets updated, the hosting component calls getDOMNode again.

With this in place, contributing plugins can use any view framework they like, provided that they satisfy the contract above.

Here's an example of how an implementation that uses Handlebars might look:

AwesomeViewContribution.js

// ES6 syntax
import viewTemplate from "./AwesomeView.handlebars"

export default function createView()  ,
    dispose()  
   
 

And here's one that renders a React component:

AwesomeViewContribution.js

import ReactDOM from "react-dom"
import AwesomeComponent from "./AwesomeComponent"

export default function createView()  /, root)
      return root
     ,
    dispose()  
   
 

Given that the above is a common pattern, we can encapsulate it into a function.  In this case we want a function that takes a React component as input, and returns an implementation of the generic view interface.

Given such a function, our React example could be simplified:

MyViewContribution.js

import   from "@cisco-dna/react-utils"
import AwesomeComponent = from "./AwesomeComponent"

return genericViewFromComponent(AwesomeComponent)

And here's how genericViewFromComponent looks:

genericViewFromComponent.js

/**
 Adapts a react component to a dna platform generic view
 */
export default function genericViewFromComponent(Component)  /, root)
        return root
       ,
      dispose()  
     
   
 

A library containing genericViewFromComponent is provided here.

Using this approach, receivers of view contributions don't have to know or care about how contributors render themselves.  The interfaces don't impose a view framework choice, aside from assuming that we're rendering DOM elements.

More About Modules

 Multiple Scripts and Libraries

When specifying contributed modules in ui-config.json, you might need to load more than one JavaScript resource.  This is possible by specifying an array:

"contributions":  

The host plugin that loads the module gets whatever is exported by the last JavaScript resource in the module array.

You might need also need to have the system require() a library defined by your JavaScript.  This will happen if you specify a require attribute.

"contributions":  
...
 

Given the contribution in the above example, the host plugin gets whatever is exported by the module being required.

Contributing CSS

You might want to add CSS content to a page if you're contributing a view.  Typically CSS will be baked into JavaScript modules via dpm/webpack, so you don't have to do anything special.  But if you have a situation where you need to load a standalone CSS asset when a module is loaded, specify a css attribute:

"contributions":  
...
 
When invoked, loadModule() API ensures that all specified CSS assets are loaded.

 Service Injection

Services can be automatically injected into modules when they are loaded, by specifying an inject property:

"contributions":  
...
 

For more information about how service injection works, take a look at the [service documentation] (  )

Common Resources

You might have JS and/or CSS that is common to all modules, that you want to ensure are required or injected prior to loading any module defined in your plugin.  You can specify these in one place so that you don't have to repeat them for every contribution in your plugin.  Do this by specifying a modulePreload attribute at the top level of your ui-config.json:

"modulePreload":  

The value of modulePreload is the same as modules specified in contributions.

 Sandboxing

It is possible to sandbox plugin contributions such that all of their code runs / renders inside of IFrames, isolating styles and the global JavaScript context from the receiving plugin.  The API for dealing with such contributions is somewhat different.  The biggest difference is that all interaction between the receiver and contributor is asynchronous.

In the examples below, we'll re-visit our search example from the first part of this document.

Contributing Plugin

Surprise!  In the search scenario, no change is needed to the contributing plugin's code!

 Hosting Plugin

Here's what the hosting plugin's code would look like if it wanted to sandbox each contributing plugin.  Changed lines are noted in the comments.

dna/core/search/Search.js

require(["core/utils/PluginContributions"], function(PluginContributions)  
  return performSearch
 )

Note that although the contributing plugin exports a synchronous API, the hosting plugin gets an aysnchronous version of it.

This is because under the hood, the hosting and contributing plugins communicate with each other via window.postMessage, which is an asynchronous mechanism for exchanging information between frames.  The value returned by getExport() is actually a proxy to the object exported by the contributing plugin.

Also note that, if the contributing plugin exports something other than an object, the hosting plugin will get a copy (via a serialize + deserialize step) of whatever it exports rather than a proxy.  Thus the contributing plugin must export a serializable value in this case.

Cleaning Up

Hosting plugins must call dispose() after they are finished with sandboxed resources:

const sandbox = contrib.renderSandbox()
const exportedStuff = sandbox.getExport()
// do things...
sandbox.dispose()

Calling dispose() removes the IFrame associated with the sandbox as well as all installed event listeners.

 Messaging API

Contributing code running inside of a sandbox can send messages to the hosting plugin:

window.__pluginSandboxContext.sendMessage("someMessage", data)

Note that data must be serializable.

Hosting plugins do the following to consume these messages:

const remove = someContribution.on("someMessage", (data) =  )

remove() can later be invoked to remove the registered listener.

Sandboxed Views

In the previous example, the hosting plugin invoked code from a contributing plugin.  But what if we want a contributing plugin to render a view inside of a sandbox?  Lets take a look at how we can do this.

 Hosting Plugin

//...
  const containerElement = document.createElement("div")
  new PluginContributions("cisco.dna.someHostingPlugin")
    .forExtensionPoint("resultsProvider")
    // render the sandbox IFrame inside of containerElement
    .map(contrib = contrib.renderSandbox(containerElement))
//...

Contributing Plugin

The contributing plugin gets a clean IFrame within which it can render whatever it wants.  In simple cases where no context is required from the hosting plugin, we can simply render to document.body:

  const myView = document.createElement("div")
  myView.textContent = "Hello, sandboxed world!"
  document.body.appendChild(myView)

Above, we don't export anything for the host plugin.  Contrast with previous UI examples, where we exported a generic view factory for hosting plugins to invoke whenever they need something to render.  Sandboxed plugins can still do this if they need context:

import viewTemplate from "./AwesomeView.handlebars"

const root = document.createElement("div")
document.body.appendChild(root)

export default  ,
  dispose()  
 

 Web Workers
 TBD

title: Dashboard Library
content:
Overview
The Dashboard Library is the place where you can view all the dashboards in the system, as well as where you go to create blank dashboards or dashboards from templates. 

As of now, the current UX pattern for allowing dashboard creation is either 1) Creating a blank dashboard or 2) Creating a dashboard from a template (you will be contributing a template).

Dashboard Library categories will only show if you have at least 1 template contributed to it.

 Config
The Dashboard Library takes contributions. You can view the samples in 

dashboardLibraryCategories:  ,
        id:  ,
        iconClass:  ,
        description:  ,
        module:  ,
        showActions:  
     ,
    required: ["title", "id", "iconClass"]
 

dashboardLibraryDashboards:  ,
        href:  ,
        id:  ,
        meta:  ,
                description:  ,
                imageSrc:  
             
         ,
        viewRef:  
     ,
    oneOf: [
         ,
         
    ]
 

As you can see, there are 2 possible configurations for a 
Module API
You may have noticed in the schema for 
Here is a short snippet of the API

    /**
    @param    viewRef the viewRef containing the template which was clicked
    @param    openSidebar a function which will open the sidebar
    @param    closeSidebar a function which will close the sidebar
    */
    export default function onClick(
        viewRef,
        openSidebar,
        closeSidebar
    )
`

title: Dashlet Library
content:
Overview
The Dashlet Library is the place where you can view all the contributed dashlet templates in the system. You can select and add Dashlets which will then appear in your Dashboard.

 Config
The Dashlet Library takes contributions. You can view the samples in 

dashletLibraryCategories:  ,
        id:  
     ,
    required: ["title", "id"]
 

dashletLibraryDashlets:  ,
        id:  ,
        viewRef:  
     ,
    required: ["categoryId", "viewRef", "id"]
 
`

title: Dashlets
content:
Overview

Dashlets are the views which display your content. Your dashlet views can be written in any framework you want, but must expose a common interface (see using a view framework for more info).

 Create a Dashlet

View
First, you need to create a view, which will be rendered as a dashlet on your dashboard.

See 
These views are like all other dashboard views and will expect a getDOMNode and dispose funciton to be present. An example of this can be found at [Generic view interface] (  )

Please note, getDOMNode may be called semi frequently, so you should try and make your getDOMNode as efficient as possible. Try to selectively update the DOM, or use a framework with virtual dom.

And of course, avoid all syncronous / sync:true ajax requests :)

Props

 Events
TBD.

Config
Now that you have created your view, you need to contribute it to the platform's view registry.  See dashlet/ui-config.js for an example of how to do this.

title: Global Filters
content:
Overview
Global Filters provide a filter which is applicable to all dashlets. Changing the value of one of these filters will send the filter value to each dashlet and will change what data it displays (if it is supported). The global filter values can be overridden by [Local Filters] (  )

 Views
There are multiple global filter views which can be configured with the dashboard. See [config] (  ) later.

An example of the views which will render in the top right next to the dashboard title are:
dashboard/src/DashboardConfig.js, dashboard/src/DashboardConfig2.js, dashboard/src/DashboardConfig3.js

The second optional view dashboard/src/DashboardConfigBottom.js will be rendered on the bottom of the header, and will take up the full width of the screen.

The last optional view dashboard/src/ToggleableDashboardConfigBottom.js is an example of a view which will slide up/down with a toggle function (see 

These views are like all other dashboard views and will expect a getDOMNode and dispose funciton to be present. An example of this can be found at [Generic view interface] (  )

Props

toggleBottomFilterArea - call this function to show/hide the bottom filter area

Now, you can use the filters by referencing the id in the following:

actionViewRefs - These are action toggles which will appear next to 
An example of usage in dashboard config is
topGlobalFilterViewRefs: [

Where the string "cisco.dna.dashboardPlugin/myFilterId" is "pluginId/filterId"

As you can see in the above example, we are contributing 2 views. One is the action, and one is the toggleable filter. When rendered, the view 
One extra piece of config is the isOpenByDefault boolean value. If set to true, upon first rendering the dashboard, the item will be default expanded. If it is not set, or it is false, it will be collapsed and hidden, requiring the user to click the action to see the filter content.

The Dashboard Framework is a core-plugin within platform_ui. It uses core concepts from the platform such as contribution model, services, and view registry to create dashboards. Everything is configured in your plugin's

title: Sidebar
DNA Plugin Manager
content:
DNA Plugin Manager

       __
  _/ /  __ _
 / _  / _ \/ _ `_ \
/ // / // / / / / / /
\,_/ ./_/ // /_/
    /_/

 What
This is a command line tool that can be used to:

Generate a new DNA UI plugin skeleton
Run plugins in dev mode, with live/hot reloading, hosting them in a remote DNA UI platform instance
Package plugins for production deployment

Why
  Provide an optimal DNA plugin development workflow out of the box, with support for ES6+, live/hot reloading, production builds, etc
  Avoid baking common dev/build logic into every plugin
  Take advantage of the latest tooling improvements via a simple yarn/npm upgrade

 Installation
Install Node.js version = 6.10, if you don't already have it.
npm -g install @cisco-dna/dpm --registry http://engci-maven-master.cisco.com/artifactory/api/npm/apic-em-npm-group/

 NOTE: If you run into permissions problems when installing with npm -g, one way around this is to run with sudo.  But we don't generally recommend this, because npm packages can run arbitrary scripts, and you don't want these scripts running as root.  See here for a way to resolve this.

Usage

 Create a plugin skeleton
dpm create projectDirectory creates a new plugin skeleton in the given directory.

Starting the dev server
Baked into DPM is a dev server which provides useful functionality for plugin development.  It transforms, bundles, and serves your plugin assets.  It also watches for file changes and performs browser hot reloading of your plugin's modules when they change.

The dev server can be started for one or more plugins.  Here are a few examples:

  dpm start in a plugin directory or dpm start /path/to/plugin for a single plugin
  dpm start /path/to/plugins/plugin1 /path/to/plugins/plugin2 for multiple plugins
  dpm start /path/to/plugins/* for all plugin subdirectories in /path/to/plugins/

During plugin development, you need access to a platform UI instance to test against.

 Point a platform UI instance at your plugin

DPM enables a workflow whereby plugins can be developed independently from the platform.  The platform instance can be remote, or can be running locally on your machine.  With this approach, the platform does not have any knowledge about where your plugin code physically resides on the file system.

Start a dev server for your plugin(s):
  For running with a remote platform instance: dpm start -s yourPluginDir.  This serves your plugin over SSL (https).
  For running with a local platform instance: dpm start yourPluginDir.
If you started dpm with -s, visit https://localhost:3002/ui-config.json and override the security warning your browser presents.  This is a one time thing.
Visit http(s)://[your-platform-cluster-ip]/developer.
Paste http(s)://localhost:3002/ui-config.json into the text field, and click the add (+) button.  Your plugin(s) should then appear in the list.

Packaging plugins for production deployment

  dpm build [pluginDirs...]  builds the plugin in the current directory or the plugins in the specified directories for production.  Note that globs (e.g. path/to/plugins/*) can be used. By default, output gets written into the dist subdirectory of each built plugin.
Options:
  --verbose Display verbose build output
  --analyze Generate a bundle analysis report

The build output written to dist contains everything you need to deploy to have your plugin run in production.

 Plugin manifests

DNA UI plugins are required to have a manifest file that describes them.  When you create a plugin sekelton via dpm create, a ui-config.js file is generated, which can be customized as needed.  Your ui-config.js exports a function that returns a data structure representing your plugin's configuration.  This configuration is what the UI platform sees at runtime.

Note that the ui-config.js script is executed at build time.
When your plugin is built via dpm build, the configuration object returned by the ui-config.js exported function is written to ui-config.json in the dist directory of your plugin.  Therefore, the return value of the function must be serializable to JSON.

Referencing modules and assets in contributions
If you're referencing your plugin's javascript modules or assets such as images within contributions, it's important to use the assetRef function to inject the path name generated for your module at build time.  For example:

myPlugin/ui-config.js
module.exports = ( ) =  ]
       
     
   
 )

Translates into something like:
myPlugin/dist/ui-config.json
"contributions":  
      ]
     

Note that the plugin module has a hash value its name.  Such files can be cached in the browser forever, because the file name will change whenever the content changes.  The assetRef function can be used to reference image, svg, and font files as well.  When used with such assets, dpm's build logic will ensure that they are copied out into the build output directory (dist by default), with hashed filename suffixes.

You can see this for yourself if you inspect the ui-config.json file that gets generated in the dist directory of your plugin after running dpm build.

 Webpack configuration
dpm uses Webpack 2.x to bundle plugin scripts and other assets.  The default configuration has the following features:

ES6 via babel-loader (presets: es2015, react, stage-2)
Hot module replacement on save
Auto remount of React components when their respective modules change
Displays compile errors in the browser and terminal
Displays runtime errors that occur in React render methods in the browser
Sass support via sass-loader
Less support via less-loader
Local CSS modules by default, via css-loader
autoprefixer (via postcss-loader)
Source Maps
Minification of production builds
Bundle size analysis via dpm build --analyze
png,jpg,gif,svg,eot,ttf,woff,woff2 data urls via file-loader

Customizing your plugin's build
You might need to customize your plugin's build.  For example, you might want to add a plugin or loader to the underlying webpack build pipeline.

To do this, create a file named dpm.config.js in the plugin's directory.  It should either export a function, or export an object containing a customize function:

module.exports =  
 

The function will be called at build time, and will be passed as input a base webpack config.  It should return a config modified to suit its needs.  The webpack-merge library is extremely useful for merging your config with the base config.  Here's an example.

Note that when referencing webpack modules that are in your plugin's devDependencies, you will likely need to use require.resolve to get an absolute path to them.  For example:

 ,
        exclude: [path.resolve(_dirname, "nodemodules")]
       
    ]
   
 

If you have a customization that you feel would be of general benefit to plugin developers, contact the dpm team.  And we're happy to entertain pull requests :-)

 Import src relative modules
The default webpack config for dpm defines ~ as an alias to the src root of your plugin.  You can use this to import modules within your code using src relative paths.  For example, a module src/foo/FooModule can be imported from elsewhere using:

src/bar/BarModule.js
import FooModule from "~/foo/FooModule"

Importing external modules
To import external AMD modules (i.e. DNA Platform API modules), prefix the module you're requiring with external.  For example:
import domReady from "external/domReady"
import PluginContributions from "external/core/utils/PluginContributions"

 Contributing
If you want to contribute to dpm, perform the following steps:
  Fork or clone this repo, and cd into it
  Run npm -g install yarn && yarn && npm link

The npm link step sets you up with a global dpm command that runs code from your locally cloned repo.  Any changes you make to the codebase will be reflected when you run the command.

Contacts
Khaled Agrama (khagrama@cisco.com)
Iain Hamilton (iaihamil@cisco.com)

title: RBAC Examples
RBAC Overview
Consuming Services
content:
Services can be consumed by plugins in various ways.

Service imports

The DNAC platform comes pre-baked with an AMD loader for platform services.  Plugins can import services just like they import regular modules.

This is the easiest way to consume services, but currently will only work for services that do not require context.  If you try to import a service that requires context using this method, you'll receive a runtime error.

 Example
import shellService from "dna-service!external/cisco.dna.core.shell/shell"

// ...

// now you can make use of shell service APIs
const queryParams = shellService.router.queryParams

Service injection
The DNAC platform has a built-in mechanism that can inject service instances into contributed modules.  Currently, this is the only way to leverage services that require context.

 Example
The below example illustrates a route view contribution that gets a persistence instance injected into it.  Any contributed module can receive service injections.

 ui-config.js

  contributions:  
     
   

The system will check to ensure that requested services are registered.  If not, an error will be logged to the console, and the associated contribution will be disregarded.

Modules that ask for services to be injected, as in the example above, must wrap what they'd normally export with a function that receives these services as inputs:

 src/MyView.js
export default function( )  

Note exported function receives an object that has the service names as keys (i.e. persistence, telemetry).  Their respective values are not direct service instances.  Instead they are functions that return promises.  This is to enable lazy loading of service modules only if/when they are actually used.

Key names of injected services can be customized.  This is to handle situations where two service names might conflict.  Example:

 ui-config.js

  contributions:  
        ]
       
     
   

Given the above, the cisco.dna.core/persistence service will be injected with the key persistence, while cisco.dna.someOtherPlugin/persistence will be injected with the key otherPersistence.

Service registry lookup

Lastly, DNAC provides a programmatic API to obtain service instances.

 Example
import serviceRegistry from "external/core/utils/serviceRegistry"

// get an instance of the shell service
serviceRegistry.getService("cisco.dna.core.shell", "shell").then(persistence =  )
`

title: Core Platform Services
content:
This page documents various services exposed by the core platform.

Persistence

The persistence service allows you to utilize the persistence store from the platform. This could be used to save user preferences, which will be saved to MongoDB and tied to the user account.

 Local Development Setup
If you do not have mongodb locally, the UI will still start and run as normal, however you will not be able to test development and persistence within the localhost environment.
To setup MondoDB for local development environment:
The easiest way is via

brew install mongodb
mkdir -p /data/db
mongod

follow this guide for more info or if you run into issues:
https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/install-mongodb-on-os-x/
Once completed start your UI via ./dev-start after MongoDB has started.

API
    set(key, value)

    get(key)

    remove(key)

 Example
You need to inject the service into your ui-plugin via ui-config.js. See Consuming Services.

    inject: ["cisco.dna.core.persistence/persistence"]

Once it is injected, you need to wrap your generic view with the persistence:

  const myWrapper = persistence =  ,
        ...
       
     
   
  export default ( ) = persistence().then(myWrapper);

You can now use the persistence API. For example, 
Telemetry

title: Exposing Services
content:
This is an advanced topic - most plugins probably don't need to do this.

Exposing a service
A plugin can advertise a service by contributing a module to the cisco.dna.core/service extension point.

 Example

 
   
 

The contributed module, (MyService.js in the example above), should export whatever it wants to expose to the world.  For example MyService.js could look like:

export default  ,
  doSomethingAwesome()  
 

Plugins can consume the above service using the id cisco.dna.myPlugin/myService.

title: Services Overview
content:
Services are a core DNAC platform mechanism that enable plugins to advertise APIs that can be consumed by other plugins.  Service modules are loaded on-demand when they're first requested.

Various services are exposed via core platform plugins, such as the persistence, telemetry, and the platform shell.

Services can optionally be provided with context that indicates which plugins are consuming them.  This can be useful for plugins that want to offer scoped APIs.  The core persistence service is an example which takes advantage of this feature.

title: Header Extensions
content:
Overview

The shell offers extension points that allow the header UI to be extended.

 Header navigation

The shell provides an extension point for adding navigation menu items to the header.  Currently navigation menu items are contributed by the Design, Policy, Provision, and Assurance plugins in DNA center.

Example

The above produces the following menu in the header:

 Properties
label - Label for the menu item
rootRoute - The parent path for which the menu item will be displayed.
defaultRoute - The route to visit when the menu item is clicked.  This does a window.pushState, rather than full page reload.
href - The route to visit when the menu item is clicked, via a full page reload. Usually you want to use defaultRoute.
identifierRoute - The parent path for which the menu item will show as selected.
position - Where to position the menu item horizontally, relative to others.

Header widgets

title: Shell Overview
content:
Responsibilities
 Route management
The primary function of the platform shell is to manage url routing between views contributed by plugins.  Typically, route view contributions will be the code execution entry point for plugins that want to render something on the screen.

When the platform loads a page, the shell takes control after the platform initializes.  It then decides which view to render based on the url visited.

The platform also offers service-based APIs that plugins can use to query and manipulate the route, and listen for route changes.

Shell UI
The shell also provides a few extension points control the display of the platform UI header.  Plugins can specify top level menus, and contribute widgets to display on the top right of the screen.  The shell also provides an API for displaying notification popups on the screen.

title: Routing
content:
Map a view to a route

Plugins can assign their views to render when particular routes are visited, by specifying a route contribution in their plugin manifest.

 Example

 ui.config.js

 
   
 

FooView.js is expected to implement the generic view interface.

Arranging views into tabs

Plugins can arrange multiple views into tabbed menus, each of which will have a unique url.

 Example

 ui.config.js

 ,
               
                    ]
                   
                 
               
            ]
           
         
       
     
   
 

The above specifies that we want to display a set of tabs at route /dna/foo.  At the top level, we have two tabs, labeled "First Tab" and "Second Tab".  The second tab has another tab nested within it, called "Nested Tab".

The specified id values determine the query parameter names and values used to construct unique urls for each tab.  Tab ids and tab container ids should therefore be unique.

Note that the above approach uses viewRef to render a pre-existing view, cisco.dna.core.shell/tabContainer, registered with the platform view registry (TBD).

Mixing in views from other plugins

In the previous example, you may have noticed that we specified values for mixinExtensionPoint.  Doing this provides an extension point name that can be used as a contribution target by other plugins to extend the tabContainer.

 Example

 ui.config.js

 
      ]
     ,
    "cisco.dna.myPlugin/fooNestedTabs":  
      ]

title: Shell Service
content:
Overview
The shell exposes a platform service with various APIs, discussed below.  The shell service can be imported like so:

 Service Id

The id of the shell service is cisco.dna.core.shell/shell.

It can be imported like so:

import shell from "dna-service!external/cisco.dna.core.shell/shell"

Router API

shell.router.location

Returns data about the current url visited in the browser, similar to window.location.

hr/

shell.router.queryParams

Returns an object with the current location's query params and values.

hr/
shell.router.push(someUrl)

Go to someUrl, pushing it onto the history stack.  This does not cause a page reload.  If you need a page reload, use window.location.

hr/
shell.router.replace(someUrl)

Go to someUrl, replacing the current url in the history stack.

hr/

shell.router.matchPath("/some/path",  )

Indicates whether or not the path given in the first param matches the criteria in the second param.  Implements the same API as the identically named function provided by react-router.

 Notification API

shell.notifications.addNotification(messageData)

Display a popup notification on the screen.  messageData should be an object with, at a minimum, the keys level, and message.  For example:

 shell.notifications.addNotification( )`

Possible messageData properites:

message - the message to display
level - the type of message ("error", "warning", or "info")
position - the position to display the notification ("br", "tr", "bl", "tl", "bc", or "tc"; b means bottom, t means top, c means center, l means left, r means right)
autoDismiss - delay in seconds for the notification go away. Defaults to 5 for info, success, and warning levels, and does not auto dismiss for error.

hr/

title: Visual Appearance
Boilerplate Contributions
content:
Using Boilerplates
Boilerplate is loaded in via the ui-config.js by simply specifying the Boilerplate(s) you wish to load and where you want to place them.

The Canvas Topology Framework provides predefined areas for contributions, that boilerplate modules or custom contributions can be placed, these are as follows:

toolbarOverlay - Used for any absolute positioned elements e.g. Popup menus, info boxes, dialogues.

toolbarLeft - Used for placing Widgets/Buttons into the top left of the Topology view.

toolbarRight - Used for placing Widgets/Buttons into the top right of the Topology view.

toolbarTools - Used for placing Widgets/Buttons/Workflows into the bottom of the Topology view.

toolbarRightSettings - An overlay that provides the subcategories Filter, View and Action for organizing of Contributions 
Available Boilerplates

The following Boilerplate Modules are available out of the box and can be optionally used within the Topology. A couple are tied to APIC-EM Topology and Inventory APIs, respectively needing the Topology to be populated with the associated API responses, these are marked as so by a .

An example of the Info Box boilerplate being used can be seen bellow. We state that the Boilerplate Contribution is for the Topology Framework, we then specify the target as cisco.dna.example.topology which matches the id we set in the Topology Properties on Topology initialization. The Contribution "InfoView" is placed into the toolbarOverlay holder.

"cisco.dna.core.topology": [
     
]

 Available Boilerplates

Info Box
Boilerplate Value: InfoView
Info box offers a default click event popup for Nodes, Links and Multiple Node selection.
    
Although tailored for the default properties supplied by the APIC-EM physical-topolgy response, it offers a good starting point if you wish to develop your own Topology info popups for click events.

 Layers 
Boilerplate Value: Layers
Allows for the toggling of layers within the Topology view. This will grey out any node which is not part of the selected Layer 2, Layer 3, or VRF user choice.

Tags 
Boilerplate Value: Tags
Allows for the toggling of any tags applied to devices via the Device Inventory API. When a tag is selected, devices with the tag applied will have colorized circles rendered around them.

 Color Coding
Boilerplate Value: ColorCoding
A simple module that allows you to toggle on and off the applied color coding of nodes. 

Links Toggle
Boilerplate Value: LinkToggle
This allows the user to switch on and off the rendering of links between nodes.

 Hosts Toggle
Boilerplate Value: HostToggle
This allows the user to switch on and off the rendering of devices with the familyType property Host between nodes. This helps de-noise your Topology and keep the rendered view optionally simpler at the users discretion.

Center View
Boilerplate Value: CenterView
Clicking this will reposition the Topology camera view to center.

 Rotate Layout
Boilerplate Value: RotateView
Clicking this will reposition the entire Topology by 90.

Aggregation
Boilerplate Value: AggregationToggle

 Multiselect
Boilerplate Value: MultiselectToggle

Capture Full Topology
Boilerplate Value: FullScreenshot

 Capture Current Topology View
Boilerplate Value: ViewScreenshot

Details
Boilerplate Value: DetailsToggle

 Search
Boilerplate Value: Search

Curved Links
Boilerplate Value: CurvedLinksToggle

 Zoom
Boilerplate Value: ZoomTools

Arrange
Boilerplate Value: Arrange

title: Boilerplate Layouts
content:
Boilerplate Layout Algorithms allow you to easily handle Physical Topology positioning without worrying about the structuring.

There are multiple default layout algorithms provided that can be easily included in your Topology. Layout algorithms within the Topology Framework are ran as individual web workers, meaning computation time is off loaded from the main thread, allowing for non blocking and faster processing.

You can define multiple Boilerplate algorithms and set one as the default, or pass through just one which will automatically be used as default. If you use the Arrange Boilerplate module listed in the previous Boilerplate section, the user can then toggle between all layouts provided.
The Boilerplate Layouts are defined for usage through the ui-config.js contribution list as follows.

"cisco.dna.core.topology": [
     ,
     ,
     
]

| Enterprise Collapsed Layout | Enterprise Expanded Layout |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
|  |  |

| Spiral Layout | Connections Layout |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
|  |  |
 

 
The Boilerplate layouts, excluding LayoutConnections, require that each node has a family and role type value, for example role: "BORDER ROUTER", family: "Routers".
 
The default role list used by pre-existing layout algorithms matches that of the APIC-EM physical-topology response:
var ROLES = [
  "cloud node",
  "BORDER ROUTER",
  "CORE",
  "DISTRIBUTION",
  "ACCESS",
  "HOST",
  "UNKNOWN"
];
 
The default role list used by pre-existing layout algorithms matches that of the APIC-EM physical-topology response:
var FAMILY = [
  "cloud node",
  "Routers",
  "Wireless Controller",
  "Switches and Hubs",
  "Cisco Interfaces and Modules",
  "Cisco UCS Series",
  "Unified AP",
  "Autonomous AP",
  "Security and VPN",
  "Unsupported Cisco Device",
  "Third Party Device",
  "WIRED",
  "WIRELESS",
  "PHONE",
  "UNKNOWN",
  "Unauthorized Device"
];
 
With each node having one of the above values set, the Boilerplatee layout algorithms should work out of the box.

title: Boilerplate Links
content:
Different Topologies require different styles of links. 

| physical-hierarchy | logical-path|
| ------------- |:-------------:|
|  |  |
 
 Similarly to all Boilerplates, custom Links contribution modules can be used, or out of the box default styling is available.

 The currently available Link styling Boilerplates can be easily loaded in as a contribution, with your Topology ID as the target via the ui-config.js as so:

 

 

if no Boilerplate or custom module is provided, the Topology will use its own default styling.

title: Custom Contribution Widgets
Example Source
FAQ
content:
What Framework does the Topology use?
The Topology is built on a contribution model developed for the DNA UI Platform. The Canvas rendering engine is built on top of JsISO, a tile engine optimized for various scales of data.

 Can I use the Canvas Topology Framework with any DNA UI Plugin Framework?
Yes, as the Topology Tool is pulled in from the Platform Service Registry there is no requirement on how you use it. Just require and pass it a DOM element.

title: Example GIFs
content:
Instant Search
Performance is achieved using the Levenshtein distance algorithm within a Web Workers to keep responsiveness high, even when scaled.

 Path Trace 

The ability for a Contribution using exposed Synthetic events and properties to render a path between a source and target populated via its own UX.

Combining the search Boilerplate flow with the Pathtrace contribution to perform a work flow.

Layers & Topology within Topology

Boilerplate that provides the ability to gray out non L2/L3/VRF devices. A second Boilerplate allows for easily creating an overlay Topology via a simple property filtering.

 Multiselect

Selecting multiple devices and hosts can be done via either cntrl + clicking one by one, or using the Multiselect Boilerplate and dragging a selection area over desired devices.

Layout Change

The Layout Contributions run their Algorithms from within Web Workers, allowing for non-blocking logic to run and handle scaled data without a UX performance hit.

 Custom Layouts and Aggregation

Aggregate and move devices freely, with the ability to save and load custom user defined layouts.

Collapse & Expand

With the optional Boilerplate, users can easily expand or collapse nodes using the defined Topology hierarchy, all executing exposed Topology Framework synthetic events.

 Position and Save Freely

Aggregate devices by dragging and dropping them on one another, apply custom labels and use the Topology APIs to store the defined layout.

Highlight Tags and Overlay or Aggregate

View devices with a particular tag, aggregate them or view them separately in a Topology Overlay.

title: Custom Contribution Icons
content:
The Canvas Topology Framework out of the box offers a default set of icons and styles for Device & Host Family associated rendering. At build time this can be easily replaced or expanded on. However there may be a case were Plugin Contributions wish to expand on the existing Family associated rendering.

An example use case of this is a package that adds support for third party devices meaning their Family value is no longer returned by both the Inventory and Topology services as unknown. Although the backend will then provide a known Family type, there is a requirement to have the Topology  render appropriately and not show an Unknown Icon.

This is achieved with an Icon Contribution.

Icon Contributions can add support, change the build time default, or further expand on properties giving more specific Icon displays. It consists of a ui-config.js that contains 

An Icon and properties for the rendering reflect the same set as those offered at build time. The Topology has a few default fonts built-in, however an Icon Contribution can provide its own as well, in the bellow example bringing in font-awesome.

contributions:  
  ]
 

This icon contribution targets the Topology with the ID cisco.dna.core.exampleTopology, providing the defined properties for any device with the Family value "Jumper Switches".

As seen in the bellow screenshot the Icon propagates throughout the full Topology.

title: Overview
content:
Overview

The Canvas Topology Framework is a flexible and easily extendable approach for rendering Physical and Logical views. The Framework is a core part of the Platform, using the Platform Contribution Model, and can be included anywhere with a few lines of code.

The core of the Framework is built on an aspect orientated approach, with the core functionality using the same hooks which are exposed for external developers and their contributions to consume.

It uses the HTML5 Canvas element and is built for both speed of loading and speed of rendering. As it is raster and not vector or DOM based, there is a lot of custom logic running in the background to track views, key items, cache graphics and interactive positioning.

The Framework is easily integrated into your page via the Service Registry as it is provided by the Platform as a Core Plugin.

 Custom Contributions

As mentioned Canvas Topology Framework allows for contributions via the Platform Contribution Model. The following list of Contributions are supported.

Widgets and Workflows

    All interactions within the Topology Framework trigger Synthetic Events. These Events can be hooked into or triggered via the provided util and aspect tools, inherited by default in every Topology Contribution.

    This allows for optional Widgets and Workflows to be provided from external sources at runtime, applying their own custom interactions as well as look and feel. Optional Boilerplate Contributions are available for standard workflows, however these can be used at developers discretion or completely replaced if a different approach or UX flow is desired.

 Layout Algorithms

    The Topology uses Web Workers for a variety of purposes to keep scaled Physical Topology data handling as fast as possible.

    One area which the Canvas Topology Framework gains a lot of performance improvement from is offloading the positioning of Topology layouts to Layout Algorithm Web Workers. The Layout Algorithms are responsible for carrying out positioning of the data by their own means, and ensuring every node within the data is given an X and Y coordinate position. These coordinate populated nodes are then sent back to the Topology Framework for rendering.

    A Layout Algorithm Contribution allows developers to write their own layout logic, producing the desired structuring they want to offer.

Link Path Style

    Different Topology views require different default link styling. One Topology use case for a Logical layout may desire all links to be straight and direct between source and target, while a Physical layout may need curved links within the hierarchy placement.

    The Topology Framework allows for a Links contribution that describes how links should look depending on where the target node sits versus the source node in the visual topology grid. Currently a link can be given a starting and ending offset, as well as two X and Y Bezier curve control points depending on 4 possible directions.

 Device Rendering Support

    The Topology Framework by default supports various Family and Role types, rendering the specified icon, color and various other properties chosen at build time. These can be easily replaced or adjusted as desired allowing for a custom appearance and ability to match UX needs.

    Via an Icon Contribution developers can further expand on the supported Family and Role types at runtime. Should a Plugin to the platform expand on supported physical devices or a developer wants to alter the appearance of a specific device based on a new property, an Icon Contribution can alter the rendering properties as well as providing its own font library to use.

Topology Performance
The key elements of keeping the Topology fast are but not limited too the following.

As it uses Canvas and not SVG, the rendering area can be controlled and only visible nodes drawn. Canvas can handle drawing many items far better than SVG, remaining at 60 Frames Per Second. Methods are incorporated to only render nodes which would be visible in the users view port.

A redraw of the Canvas Context only occurs when an interaction is made, otherwise it remains as a static image. This allows for multiple Topologies per page without any impact to rendering.

SVG Icons via Font Icon packs (NeXt & Prime Fonts or Contributed Fonts) are converted to PNG offscreen and then cached when a specific request is made for one. The cached PNG version is then used on every other draw request. This keeps the sharp Vector quality without the increased cost of Vector rendering.

Links between nodes are drawn as a single polygon, keeping individual draw requests limited were possible.

A lot of the logic is highly optimized e.g. loops, maths etc.

WebWorkers are used for layout algorithms and Levenshtein distance search.

title: Initializing Basics
User Interaction
Custom Contribution Layouts
Custom Contribution Links
content:
Custom Links Style Overview

A link contribution can be loaded in via the ui-config.js. The extension point in this case is "links".

A custom Link contribution describes the basic appearance of a link in the Topology view. 

Currently this works as a directional system, rendering links in a specific way depending on where the target node sits from the beginning source node. These directions are above, bellow, left (inline), right (inline). A default is also available which is used for when a Node is being dragged by the user.

Each directional property supports an x1 and y1, which describes any initial offset from the center of the node. This allows for links to travel in a direction before heading in the direction of the target.

Each direction property supports a cp1x, cp1y, cp2x and cp2y, which are the control points for your Bezier curve. For more information on Bezier curve control points see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/bezierCurveTo. These values are relative to the starting position and optionally set x1 and y1 offsets. 

Lastly each direction property supports an x2 and y2 value, which control any offset before the centre of the ending target node. Again this is relative.

Lastly a links contribution can provide settings for how the link should end at both the source and target. Right now only a circular shape and color is supported. Note, this requires use of the x1,y1 and x2,y2 properties as this will be where the ending image is rendered.

The best way to get the exact look and feel you're after is to load an existing link contribution source, and play with the numbers until the Bezier control points make sense.

In the future further shapes, or ability to contribute shapes will be supported, as well as endless control points. 

 Example Link Contribution

The bellow example source would render links as the following image displays to a tagret topology with the match id "cisco.dna.myExampleTopology".

 

export const style =  ,
    left:  ,
    right:  ,
    above:  ,
    below:  
   ,
  linkEnds:  ,
    target:  
   
 ;
`

title: Backbone/Marionette
content:
Overview
The platform provides a utility function, genericViewFromBackboneView, to simplify contribution of views ([shell routes] (  ), for example) that are implemented using Backbone/Marionette.

It wraps such views with an implementation of the [generic view interface] (  ).

Example
import genericViewFromBackboneView from "external/core/utils/genericViewFromBackboneView"

const MyView = Backbone.View.Extend( )

export default genericViewFromBackboneView(MyView)

A template string can be passed in as an option to genericViewFromBackboneView.  This template will be rendered into the DOM prior to rendering the view:

import MyTemplate from "raw-loader!./MyTemplate.html"

export default genericViewFromBackboneView(MyView,  )

Note that Marionette views require a template property to be set in the view itself.  If there is no associated template, set the value to _.noop.

title: View Framework Overview
content: The platform doesnt care how your plugin renders views, so long as it can return a DOM node when asked. More discussion on this here.

title: React
content:
For React users, a utility library, @cisco-dna/react-utils, is provided to easily adapt React components to platform generic views, and vice-versa.

Example
Look here for a working example that illustrates how to contribute React based views.

 React components
Also provided out of the box is a set of React components that can be used within plugins.

To use them via a DPM based plugin, make sure that your dpm.config.js looks like this:

dpm.config.js
module.exports =  

Component documentation can be found here.

**Note that the documentation is currently somewhat out of date:

import   from "@cisco-dna/react-components"

title: Why Web Components?
content:
DNA Web Components

DNA Web Components allow you to have a single implementation of DNA widgets - no need for separate JQuery, React, Angular, etc implementations. It is based on web standards providing a modular approach for web development.

Use from anywhere - they're just html tags / DOM elements. 

 Example 

//* React *//
import React from 'react';
import   from 'external/@cisco-dna/dnx-react-components';

const data = [ ,  ,  ];

class DonutSample extends React.Component  
            maintitle='Pie Chart Title'
            labels= 
        /DnxDonut
        <);
     
 
export default DonutSample;

//* JQuery *//

define(['external/@cisco-dna/dnx-web-components'],function()  ,  ,  ];

    const internaltext=[ ]

    function _onClickSlice(event)  
    const chart = $("dnx-donut-chart /")
    chart.prop( )
    $(document.body).append(chart)
    $('dnx-donut-chart').on("onClickSlice",  , function (event)  );
 )

Current List 

We update this list on regular basis as we move new components. Stay tuned!

[Donuts] (/guides/webcomponents/pie)
[Timeline Chart] (/guides/webcomponents/timeline)
[Line Chart] (/guides/webcomponents/timeline)
[Area Chart] (/guides/webcomponents/area)
